dashboard_config.title: Malaria Program Review (MPR)
dashboard_config.subtitle: Analysis and System Design
dashboard_config.tagline: A local firm with international standards

sections.title: Malaria Program Review (MPR) Introduction
sections.content: The Malaria Program Review (MPR) is a comprehensive, country-led assessment designed to evaluate the performance, relevance, and impact of all aspects of a national malaria response. For the National Malaria Control Programme (NMCP) in Sierra Leone, the MPR is a critical opportunity to reflect on progress, identify gaps, and re-align priorities with the evolving malaria epidemiology, global best practices, and national health goals.

sections.title: Purpose of the MPR
sections.content: The main purpose of the MPR is to ensure that the malaria program remains efficient, effective, and results-oriented. It supports evidence-based planning and strengthens program accountability, coordination, and resource allocation. The MPR also prepares the groundwork for the development of new strategic plans and funding proposals to partners such as the Global Fund and PMI.

sections.title: Key Focus Areas of the Review
sections.content:
‚Ä¢ Prevention Strategies: Evaluation of long-lasting insecticidal net (LLIN) mass campaigns, routine distribution through antenatal clinics (ANC) and immunization platforms (EPI), and School-Based Distribution (SBD). Assessment of Indoor Residual Spraying (IRS) coverage and impact where implemented.
‚Ä¢ Case Management and Diagnosis: Availability and use of rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) and microscopy in health facilities, timely access to quality-assured antimalarial drugs, and training/supervision of health workers on treatment guidelines.
‚Ä¢ Surveillance, Monitoring, and Evaluation: Review of data collection, reporting, and use of DHIS2; assessment of test positivity rates, incidence, and mortality trends; and evaluation of community-based surveillance.
‚Ä¢ Community Engagement and Social Behaviour Change: Effectiveness of SBCC strategies, community ownership, and the role of SBD in empowering school children as malaria prevention champions.
‚Ä¢ Programme Governance and Coordination: Review of institutional capacity, partnerships between MoHS and MBSSE, and financing mechanisms for malaria interventions.

sections.title: Relevance of School-Based ITN Distribution
sections.content:
The School-Based Distribution (SBD) of Insecticide-Treated Nets (ITNs) is a promising intervention that addresses the challenge of maintaining universal ITN coverage between mass campaigns. Its integration into the MPR highlights considerations such as:
‚Ä¢ Coverage and Equity: Assessment of SBD coverage in classes 1, 3, and 5, including marginalized groups.
‚Ä¢ Partnerships: Operational collaboration between health and education sectors.
‚Ä¢ Outcomes: Usage rates, knowledge of ITN care, and its impact on malaria morbidity among school-age children.

sections.title: Expected Benefits & Conclusion
sections.content:
Expected Benefits of the Review
‚Ä¢ Provide an evidence base to validate SBD as an effective strategy for achieving universal ITN coverage.
‚Ä¢ Identify best practices and challenges in current malaria interventions to inform future programming.
‚Ä¢ Strengthen inter-ministerial collaboration for sustained delivery of integrated services.
‚Ä¢ Guide the development of a new malaria strategic plan (2026‚Äì2030), incorporating innovative, equitable, and data-driven strategies.

Conclusion
The Malaria Program Review is not just a routine assessment; it is a strategic pivot point for NMCP to enhance impact, secure sustained funding, and ultimately achieve malaria elimination goals. With interventions like the School-Based ITN Distribution gaining traction, Sierra Leone is well-positioned to redefine its malaria control architecture with a stronger emphasis on integration, innovation, and inclusiveness.

sections.title: üìã Key Findings and Conclusions
sections.content: The Malaria Program Review has revealed significant achievements in malaria control efforts across Sierra Leone, while also identifying critical areas for improvement and future focus.

sections.title: üéØ Strategic Recommendations
sections.content:
Priority Recommendations:
‚Ä¢ Strengthen integrated vector management approaches
‚Ä¢ Enhance community engagement and ownership
‚Ä¢ Improve data quality and utilization
‚Ä¢ Scale-up innovative interventions like School-Based Distribution
‚Ä¢ Strengthen health system capacity and resilience

sections.title: üöÄ Implementation Roadmap
sections.content:
Next Steps for 2025-2030:
‚Ä¢ Develop comprehensive implementation guidelines
‚Ä¢ Establish monitoring and evaluation frameworks
‚Ä¢ Secure sustainable financing mechanisms
‚Ä¢ Build partnerships for program sustainability
‚Ä¢ Prepare for malaria elimination phase

sections.title: ü§ù Partners and Collaborators
sections.content:
Key Partners and Collaborators:
‚Ä¢ Ministry of Health and Sanitation
‚Ä¢ National Malaria Control Programme (NMCP)
‚Ä¢ President's Malaria Initiative (PMI)
‚Ä¢ World Health Organization (WHO)
‚Ä¢ Clinton Health Access Initiative (CHAI)
‚Ä¢ Abt Associates
‚Ä¢ School administrators and teachers
‚Ä¢ School Quality Assurance (SQA) officers
‚Ä¢ PHU staff and community health workers

sections.title: üôè Special Thanks
sections.content:
We extend our sincere gratitude to all stakeholders who contributed to the success of this Malaria Program Review. Special recognition goes to the communities, health workers, and education sector partners who made this comprehensive analysis possible.

Together, we are building a malaria-free Sierra Leone.
